data.title: Sherlock Holmes has a long history on film and TV
data.meta_description: More than 100 actors have played Sherlock Holmes on screen over a span of more than 100 years. Here's a quick trip through Holmesian history with 33 notable screen Sherlocks.
data.text:
Sherlock.jpg

Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman are Holmes and Watson in the "Sherlock" mysteries that air on PBS.

(Hartswood Films/BBC)

CLEVELAND, Ohio -- The Blu Ray release of "Sherlock Holmes: The Complete Granada Television Series" by MPI Home Video is a stirring reminder of how brilliant Jeremy Brett was as Arthur Conan Doyle's master detective. When it comes to superior Sherlocks, Brett stands at the head of the class, but it's a crowded field.

More than 100 actors have played Holmes on screen over a span of more than 100 years. Since the first known movie version in 1905, there have been more than 250 films featuring Holmes. That doesn't count the dozens upon dozens of TV episodes featuring everyone from Ronald Howard in the 1950s to Brett in the '80s and '90s to today's prime-time Sherlocks,

and Jonny Lee Miller on CBS.

That's good enough for the Guinness World Records, which gives Holmes the title of

Here's a quick trip through Holmesian history with 33 notable screen Sherlocks:

William Gillette --

The American actor was the first great interpreter of Holmes, having played the detective in a Doyle-authorized stage play since 1899. A 1916 film version was long thought to be lost. It was announced a month ago that a copy found in France is being restored and will get an American premiere next year.

Eille Norwood --

The British actor played Holmes in 47 silent films made over a two-year span starting in 1921. His Sherlock run included 45 short subjects and two features: "The Hound of the Baskervilles" (1921) and "The Sign of the Four" (1923).

John Barrymore --

The Great Profile played the great detective in a 1922 silent film that featured Roland Young ("Topper") as Watson and a young William Powell (the future star of "The Thin Man" making his screen debut).

Clive Brook --

The British actor played Holmes in three Hollywood films: "The Return of Sherlock Holmes" (1929), "Sherlock Holmes" (1932) and "Paramount on Parade" (a 1930 revue that included a segment with Holmes and other detectives).

Raymond Massey --

The American actor best known for playing Abraham Lincoln on stage and film in "Abe Lincoln in Illinois" portrayed Holmes in the 1931 British movie "The Speckled Band."

Arthur Wontner --

The London native portrayed Holmes in five films: "The Sleeping Cardinal" (1931), "The Missing Rembrandt" (1932), "The Sign of Four" (1932), "The Triumph of Sherlock Holmes" (1935) and "Silver Blaze" (a 1937 release also known as "Murder at the Baskervilles").

Reginald Owen --

The British star was one of a handful of screen Sherlocks also to have played Watson. He had been Watson to Brook's Holmes in 1932. Then he played Holmes in a 1933 film version of "A Study in Scarlet."

Basil Rathbone --

Between Gillette and Brett, he was the actor most identified with Doyle's character. Rathbone played Holmes in 14 films (1939-46), on radio (again with Nigel Bruce as his Watson) and in a 1953 TV production.

Ronald Howard --

The son of actor Leslie Howard ("The Petrified Forest," "Gone With the Wind"), he starred in the 1954-55 British series "Sherlock Holmes."

Peter Cushing --

The Hammer Film star made an excellent Holmes in the British studio's 1959 version of "The Hound of the Baskervilles." He also replaced Douglas Wilmer for the last year of the 1965-68 BBC television series "Sherlock Holmes." He returned to the role in 1984 for the film "The Masks of Death."

Christopher Lee --

Cushing's Hammer co-star in "The Curse of Frankenstein," "Horror of Dracula" and "The Hound of the Baskervilles" took on the role for "Sherlock Holmes and the Deadly Necklace" (1962). He played an older Holmes in two early '90s TV films with Patrick Macnee as Watson: "Sherlock Holmes and the Leading Lady" and "Incident at Victoria Falls."

John Neville --

The British actor, who later played Holmes to great acclaim on stage, had top billing in "A Study in Terror," a 1965 film that pitted the detective against Jack the Ripper. A young Judi Dench was in the cast, and Donald Houston made an excellent Watson.

Robert Stephens --

He was the star of director Billy Wilder's "The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes."

Stewart Granger --

The swashbuckling star of "Scaramouche" and "The Prisoner of Zenda" traded his sword for a deerstalker, playing Holmes in a 1972 TV movie version of "The Hound of the Baskervilles." Bernard Fox was his Watson. It was supposed to be the first of several TV movies, but poor ratings doomed those plans.

Roger Moore --

Having already played the Saint and James Bond, Moore tackled the title role in the 1976 TV movie "Sherlock Holmes in New York."

was his Watson.

Nicol Williamson --

The Scottish actor played Holmes in "The Seven-Per-Cent Solution," the 1976 film version of Nicholas Meyer's 1974 novel about the detective meeting Sigmund Freud. Robert Duvall made an amazing Watson.

Christopher Plummer --

He played Holmes twice: in the 1977 TV movie "Silver Blaze" and director Bob Clark's 1979 film, "Murder By Decree," which again pitted the sleuth against Jack the Ripper.

Peter Cook --

He and comedy partner Dudley Moore played Holmes and Watson for laughs in the 1978 spoof "The Hound of the Baskervilles."

Frank Langella --

Having played the role in a 1977 stage revival of the Gillette play, he took this performance to television for a 1981 HBO presentation.

Ian Richardson --

He played Holmes in two 1983 films made for British television: "The Sign of Four" and "The Hound of the Baskervilles."

Jeremy Brett --

His acclaimed 1984-1994 run as Holmes in the Granada series reached 36 hour episodes and five films.

Nicholas Rowe --

He plays a teenage Sherlock in director Barry Levinson's "Young Sherlock Holmes" (1985).

Edward Woodward --

The star of the horror film "The Wicker Man" and the CBS series "The Equalizer" played Holmes for a British TV film "Hands of a Murderer" (1990). John Hillerman (Higgins on "Magnum, p.i.") was his Watson.

Charlton Heston --

He took the stage play "Crucifer of Blood" to television for a Turner Network Televison film that aired in 1991.

Patrick Macnee --

Having already played Watson three times, Macnee portrayed Holmes in "The Hounds of London," a 1993 TV movie.

Matt Frewer --

He played Holmes in four films produced for the Hallmark Channel: "The Hound of the Baskervilles" (2000), "The Royal Scandal" (2001), "The Sign of Four" (2001) and "The Case of the Whitechapel Vampire" (2002).

Richard Roxburgh --

The Australian actor played Holmes in a 2002 television adaptation of "The Hound of the Baskervilles."

Rupert Everett --

The British actor depicted the detective in the 2004 British TV film "Sherlock Holmes and the Case of the Silk Stocking."

Jonathan Pryce --

He took on the role for a 2007 British TV film "Sherlock Holmes and the Baker Street Irregulars."

Robert Downey Jr. --

His two big-screen turns were "Sherlock Holmes" (2009) and "Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows" (2011).

Benedict Cumberbatch --

Nine "Sherlock" films have been made since 2010. Filming on three more starts in 2015, with Martin Freeman back as John Watson.

Jonny Lee Miller --

He has top billing in "Elementary," the CBS modern update that premiered in September 2012.

Ian McKellen --

He is playing Holmes at 93 in director Bill Condon's "Mr. Holmes," a film that will be released in 2015.

Among the many actors to have played Holmes on stage are: Gillette, Fritz Weaver (in the musical "Baker Street"), John Wood, Neville, Leonard Nimoy, Keith Michell, Keith Baxter, Ron Moody, Langella, Brett and Heston.
